profileText: A Delegate from the Territory of Washington; born in West Middletown, Washington County, Pa., November 18, 1815; attended the public schools and McKeever Academy, West Middletown, Pa.; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1843 and commenced practice; member of the State house of representatives in 1843; elected prothonotary of Washington County; appointed associate justice of the supreme court of the Territory of Oregon in 1853 and of the Territory of Washington in 1854 and served as chief justice of the latter from 1858 to 1861; member of the legislative council and chosen its president in 1861; resumed the practice of law in Olympia, Wash., and also engaged in agricultural pursuits; elected as a Democrat to the Forty-third Congress (March 4, 1873-March 3, 1875); was not a candidate for renomination in 1874; died in Olympia, Wash., June 25, 1875; interment in the Masonic Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Teiser, Stanley. "Obadiah B. McFadden, Oregon and Washington Territorial Judge." Oregon Historical Quarterly 66 (March 1965): 25-37.

researchRecord.name: 1859, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Obadiah B. McFadden to the Election Board at Tumwater, instructing the Board that it may accept votes from residents of 20 days provided they have been residents of the Territory for six months.

recordLocation.name: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

researchRecord.name: In the William Winlock Miller Collection, 1845-1958, 16 boxes.
researchRecord.description: Subjects include Obadiah Benton McFadden. An unpublished finding aid is available in the repository.

recordLocation.name: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

researchRecord.name: In the Territory of Washington vs. Watsersmi, 1854-1855, 6 pages.
researchRecord.description: The brief, written by Elwood Evans, outlines the reasons why the defendant should be discharged. A verdict had been rendered by a jury and a warrant issued to hang the defendant, but Judge O. B. McFadden issued a supersedeas and the Supreme Court decided that there was no judgment and nothing to review. The brief is also available on microfilm.

recordLocation.name: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

researchRecord.name: In the McMicken Family Papers 1828-1921, 1.83 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Major correspondents include Obadiah Benton McFadden. A finding aid is available in the repository.
